items.title: Drop support for Python 2
items.body:
Since Python 2 is now officially unsupported upstream, pluggy 1.0 is a good point to drop support for it.

Projects which want to keep support for Python 2 should keep using pluggy 0.6.x series. Pluggy 1.0 will use `python_requires = >=3.5` such that `pip install pluggy` on Python 2 projects will keep getting the 0.6.x series.

The benefits of doing this are:
- Ability to drop Python 2 compatibility code
- Ability to use Python 3-only features, like type annotation syntax, `gen.throw()`, `return` from generator, `yield from` syntax, type annotation syntax and others.
- Less CI/maintenane stuff.

In terms of big projects:

- pytest>=5 is Python 3 only. Old 4.6.x branch supports Python2, uses `pluggy>=0.12,<1.0`, so it's good.

- tox still supports Python 2, though seems to have a 4.0.0 version in development which will drop support for it (I think?). It is requiring pluggy using `pluggy>=0.12.0` , if this is accepted I'll them a PR which changes this to `pluggy>=0.12.0,<1.0.0`.

- devpi seems to have two components which use `pluggy`. The `server` component dropped Python 2. The `client` component supports Python 2 but uses `pluggy>=0.6.0,<1.0` so should be fine.

items.title: Drop official support for Python 3.4
items.body:
Python 3.4 is no longer supported by upstream, and various things like Github Actions don't support it. If we also end up dropping support for Python 2, then Python 3.4 would also hold up using type annotations syntax if we ever want to use it (see #225 for old work on that, using comment syntax).

I propose we drop it from setup.cfg classifiers, setup.py `python_requires` and CI in master (which will become a breaking change release, pluggy 1.0.0).

items.title: default multicall swallows exceptions thrown by hook implementations that do not inherit from BaseException
items.body:
While using pytest-4.6.5 and pluggy-0.13.1 in python-2.7.6 I noticed a strange issue where some exceptions being thrown by a third-party library weren't being caught by pytest and the test reported passed. I tracked the issue down to the third-party library using exception classes that don't inherit from BaseException and the try/except/finally/return pattern used by `pluggy.callers._multicall` swallowing such exceptions.

Here's a simple repro case which is expected to raise an exception but does not. If you replace the Error class with one that inherits from BaseException then it works as expected:

```python
import pluggy

hookimpl = pluggy.HookimplMarker('test')
hookspec = pluggy.HookspecMarker('test')


class Error: pass


class HookSpecs(object):
    @hookspec
    def dummy_hook(self):
        pass


class Plugin(object):
    @hookimpl
    def dummy_hook(self):
        raise Error


manager = pluggy.PluginManager('test')
manager.add_hookspecs(HookSpecs)
manager.register(Plugin())
manager.hook.dummy_hook()  # expected to raise Error
```

I tracked this all the way to the `pluggy.callers._multicall` function which uses the following try/except/finally/return pattern (pseudo code) that causes the issue:
```python
    def _multicall(...):
        results = []
        exc_info = None
        try:
            try:
                for hook_impl in reversed(hook_impls):
                    results.append(hook_impl.function(...))
            except BaseException:  # <------- problematic line
                exc_info = sys.exc_info()
        finally:
            if exc_info:
                reraise(*exc_info)
            return results[0] if results else None
```
If you change that except statement to be a bare except then everything works as expected.

Here's a simple example that demonstrates the issue. This will always print "None" and will never raise Error:
```python
class Error: pass

def test():
    result = None
    try:
        try:
            raise Error
        except BaseException:
            result = 'handled base exception'
    finally:
        return result

print(test())
```

Are there reasons for catching only BaseException subclasses and ignoring others? I couldn't think of one but that doesn't mean there isn't one :)

items.body:
I am packaging this project for EPEL8, and one constraint is that we have to use the old pytest available (3.4.2). This causes the following build errors:

```
pytest testing
============================= test session starts =============================
platform linux -- Python 3.6.8, pytest-3.4.2, py-1.8.0, pluggy-0.6.0
rootdir: /home/alfredo/python/pluggy, inifile: tox.ini
collected 17 items / 5 errors

ERROR testing/test_helpers.py
ERROR testing/test_hookcaller.py
ERROR testing/test_multicall.py
ERROR testing/test_pluginmanager.py
ERROR testing/test_tracer.py

ImportError while importing test module '/home/alfredo/python/pluggy/testing/test_helpers.py'.
Hint: make sure your test modules/packages have valid Python names.

testing/test_helpers.py:1: in <module>

testing/test_hookcaller.py:4: in <module>
    from pluggy.hooks import HookImpl
E   ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pluggy.hooks'
_________________ ERROR collecting testing/test_multicall.py __________________
ImportError while importing test module '/home/alfredo/python/pluggy/testing/test_multicall.py'.
Hint: make sure your test modules/packages have valid Python names.
Traceback:
testing/test_multicall.py:3: in <module>
    from pluggy.hooks import HookImpl
E   ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pluggy.hooks'
_______________ ERROR collecting testing/test_pluginmanager.py ________________
ImportError while importing test module '/home/alfredo/python/pluggy/testing/test_pluginmanager.py'.
Hint: make sure your test modules/packages have valid Python names.
Traceback:
testing/test_pluginmanager.py:14: in <module>
    from pluggy.manager import importlib_metadata
E   ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pluggy.manager'
___________________ ERROR collecting testing/test_tracer.py ___________________
ImportError while importing test module '/home/alfredo/python/pluggy/testing/test_tracer.py'.
Hint: make sure your test modules/packages have valid Python names.
Traceback:
testing/test_tracer.py:1: in <module>
    from pluggy._tracing import TagTracer
E   ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pluggy._tracing'
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Interrupted: 5 errors during collection !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
=========================== 5 error in 0.11 seconds ===========================
```

The interesting part here is pytest's report of installed versions:

```
platform linux -- Python 3.6.8, pytest-3.4.2, py-1.8.0, pluggy-0.6.0
```

Pluggy 0.6.0 does not have these modules, hence the `ModuleNotFoundError`. The same can be replicated by using the current tip of master with pytest. The tests do pass... but that is because it is importing the (again) pluggy version installed with pytest:

```
pytest testing
============================= test session starts =============================
platform linux -- Python 3.6.8, pytest-5.2.4, py-1.8.0, pluggy-0.13.0
```

Finally, I tried adding a `raise RuntimeError('fail')` at the top of every module in the checked out repository and the tests all passed. This should never happen:

```
pytest testing/test_helpers.py
============================= test session starts =============================
platform linux -- Python 3.6.8, pytest-5.2.4, py-1.8.0, pluggy-0.13.0
rootdir: /home/alfredo/python/pluggy, inifile: tox.ini
collected 5 items

============================== 5 passed in 0.01s ==============================

diff --git a/src/pluggy/hooks.py b/src/pluggy/hooks.py
index 0a1c287..15cbd2c 100644
--- a/src/pluggy/hooks.py
+++ b/src/pluggy/hooks.py
@@ -1,3 +1,4 @@
+raise RuntimeError('fail')
 """
 Internal hook annotation, representation and calling machinery.
 """
```

Would you consider moving the `testing` inside the pluggy module so that tests can accurately test `pluggy` itself? I tried relative imports but those didn't quite work:

```
E   ValueError: attempted relative import beyond top-level package
```

items.title: [Bug] WinError 3 FileNotFoundError
items.body:
First, I want to thank you for creating and maintaining my No.1 Favorite Python Testing Library. (+ it's core dependency pluggy) During my usage of PyTest, I encountered a peculiar bug.

## Notice
I found that this Error doesn't occur in Pytest 4.3.1 + pluggy 0.9.0 

## My Environment
Windows 10 Pro
intel i5 cpu
Python 3.7
latest PyTest (5.2.1)
pluggy 0.13.0

## What I did
I created new project, fresh virtual envrionment, test.py file

```
# test.py
def test():
    assert True
```
1. I activated the virtual envrionment
2. pip install pytest
3. pytest

## What I was expecting
to pytest finish smoothly.

## What actually happened
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Program Files\JetBrains\PyCharm 2019.2.2\helpers\pycharm\_jb_pytest_runner.py", line 4, in <module>
    import pytest
  File "C:\Users\aliwo\PycharmProjects\choco\venv\lib\site-packages\pytest.py", line 7, in <module>
    from _pytest.assertion import register_assert_rewrite
  File "C:\Users\aliwo\PycharmProjects\choco\venv\lib\site-packages\_pytest\assertion\__init__.py", line 12, in <module>
    from _pytest.assertion import rewrite
  File "C:\Users\aliwo\PycharmProjects\choco\venv\lib\site-packages\_pytest\assertion\rewrite.py", line 23, in <module>
    from _pytest.assertion import util
  File "C:\Users\aliwo\PycharmProjects\choco\venv\lib\site-packages\_pytest\assertion\util.py", line 10, in <module>
    import _pytest._code
  File "C:\Users\aliwo\PycharmProjects\choco\venv\lib\site-packages\_pytest\_code\__init__.py", line 6, in <module>
    from .code import Code  # noqa
  File "C:\Users\aliwo\PycharmProjects\choco\venv\lib\site-packages\_pytest\_code\code.py", line 15, in <module>
    import pluggy
  File "C:\Users\aliwo\PycharmProjects\choco\venv\lib\site-packages\pluggy\__init__.py", line 16, in <module>
    from .manager import PluginManager, PluginValidationError
  File "C:\Users\aliwo\PycharmProjects\choco\venv\lib\site-packages\pluggy\manager.py", line 11, in <module>
    import importlib_metadata
  File "C:\Users\aliwo\PycharmProjects\choco\venv\lib\site-packages\importlib_metadata\__init__.py", line 547, in <module>
    __version__ = version(__name__)
  File "C:\Users\aliwo\PycharmProjects\choco\venv\lib\site-packages\importlib_metadata\__init__.py", line 509, in version
    return distribution(distribution_name).version
  File "C:\Users\aliwo\PycharmProjects\choco\venv\lib\site-packages\importlib_metadata\__init__.py", line 482, in distribution
    return Distribution.from_name(distribution_name)
  File "C:\Users\aliwo\PycharmProjects\choco\venv\lib\site-packages\importlib_metadata\__init__.py", line 183, in from_name
    dist = next(dists, None)
  File "C:\Users\aliwo\PycharmProjects\choco\venv\lib\site-packages\importlib_metadata\__init__.py", line 452, in <genexpr>
    return (item for item in root.iterdir()
  File "C:\Users\aliwo\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python37\lib\pathlib.py", line 1074, in iterdir
    for name in self._accessor.listdir(self):
FileNotFoundError: [WinError 3] 'C:\\Users\\aliwo\\PycharmProjects\\choco\\ '
```

## Fix
I could fix the bug by modifing python pathlib
in pathlib.py line 1074:
```
for name in self._accessor.listdir(self): # where the exception happens
```
I changed it like below.
```
        try:
            temp = self._accessor.listdir(self)
        except:
            temp = self._accessor.listdir()
        for name in temp:
```
it worked like charm! but I know that it is not quite the fix I wanted. I wouldn't risk arbitrally modifing the python internal library.

## Fix 2
Downgrading pytest and pluggy worked like I metioned earlier.
downgrading only pytest to 4.3.1 won't work.
downgrading only pluggy to 0.9.0 won't work.
pytest 4.3.1 + pluggy 0.9.0 = Fix!

items.title: Use standard library importlib.metadata on Python 3.8
items.body: Once we update Python in Fedora to 3.8, we'd like our pluggy package to use `importlib.metadata` from the standard library. Would you accept a PR that makes the dependency on external `importlib_metadata` optional (only use it on Python < 3.8)?

items.title: Test builds at travis failing since release of pluggy v0.12
items.body:
Hi all,
Our test builds at [StarKit](https://github.com/starkit) began to unexpectedly fail since last 3 days. I checked this by doing some random changes in readme (https://travis-ci.org/jaladh-singhal/starkit/jobs/538727910) and they were still failing with same error:
```bash
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/tmp/starkit-test-k6s1wpex/lib.linux-x86_64-3.6/starkit/_astropy_init.py", line 111, in test
    coverage=coverage, open_files=open_files, **kwargs)
  File "/home/travis/miniconda2/envs/starkit/lib/python3.6/site-packages/astropy/tests/runner.py", line 518, in run_tests
    return super(TestRunner, self).run_tests(**kwargs)
  File "/home/travis/miniconda2/envs/starkit/lib/python3.6/site-packages/astropy/tests/runner.py", line 206, in run_tests
    return pytest.main(args=args, plugins=self.keywords['plugins'])
  File "_pytest.config", line 38, in main
  File "_pytest.config", line 117, in _prepareconfig
  File "_pytest.vendored_packages.pluggy", line 724, in __call__
  File "_pytest.vendored_packages.pluggy", line 338, in _hookexec
  File "_pytest.vendored_packages.pluggy", line 333, in <lambda>
  File "_pytest.vendored_packages.pluggy", line 595, in execute
  File "_pytest.vendored_packages.pluggy", line 249, in _wrapped_call
  File "_pytest.helpconfig", line 28, in pytest_cmdline_parse
  File "_pytest.vendored_packages.pluggy", line 278, in get_result
  File "_pytest.vendored_packages.pluggy", line 264, in __init__
  File "_pytest.vendored_packages.pluggy", line 596, in execute
  File "_pytest.config", line 852, in pytest_cmdline_parse
  File "_pytest.config", line 957, in parse
  File "_pytest.config", line 918, in _preparse
  File "_pytest.vendored_packages.pluggy", line 501, in load_setuptools_entrypoints
  File "/home/travis/miniconda2/envs/starkit/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2433, in load
    self.require(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/travis/miniconda2/envs/starkit/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2456, in require
    items = working_set.resolve(reqs, env, installer, extras=self.extras)
  File "/home/travis/miniconda2/envs/starkit/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 791, in resolve
    raise VersionConflict(dist, req).with_context(dependent_req)
pkg_resources.ContextualVersionConflict: (importlib-metadata 0.0.0 (/home/travis/miniconda2/envs/starkit/lib/python3.6/site-packages), Requirement.parse('importlib-metadata>=0.12'), {'pluggy'})
The command "python setup.py $SETUP_CMD" exited with 1.
```
I further investigated and found that pluggy has been recently updated to v0.12.0 (on May 28) and since then only our travis builds are failing that are using `SETUP_CMD='test --coverage'`. FYI, it is an [Astropy testing framework](http://docs.astropy.org/en/stable/development/testguide.html#setup-py-test) that runs pytest by passing option `coverage` to generate a coverage report.
As much as I could understand, I noticed that pluggy is never used by us directly, it is somehow used by pytest under the hood (I may be wrong)?! Thus I resorted here to inform you about the issue to help us solve the problem. Is it somehow related to issue https://github.com/pytest-dev/pluggy/issues/205?

Thanks in advance. Please let's try to fix this soon :)

items.title: Support PyPy3?
items.body: I see that pluggy supports PyPy, but does it support PyPy3? In Gentoo, [we have a failing test](https://bugs.gentoo.org/648672) when running tests under PyPy3.

items.title: Consider using 'entrypoints' instead of 'pkg_resources' in the future
items.body:
Came across [entrypoints](https://entrypoints.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html) on https://github.com/anthony-tuininga/cx_Freeze/issues/216#issuecomment-435270807, where @jaraco mentions that he considers `pkg_resources` soft-deprecated and recommends `entrypoints` as replacement.

I've made two very simple benchmarks on a `pytest` environment which has some plugins installed:

```python
# use_pkg_resources.py
import pkg_resources
print([x.name for x in pkg_resources.iter_entry_points('pytest11')])
```

```python
# use_entrypoints.py
import entrypoints
print([x.name for x in entrypoints.get_group_all('pytest11')])
```

```console
λ python use_pkg_resources.py
['xdist', 'xdist.looponfail', 'parallel', 'pytest_forked', 'hypothesispytest']
```

```console
λ python use_entrypoints.py
['hypothesispytest', 'pytest_forked', 'parallel', 'xdist', 'xdist.looponfail']
```

Timings on my Windows 10 machine with Python 3.6 (only showing time in milliseconds):

```
λ powershell -command "Measure-Command { python use_entrypoints.py }"
...
TotalMilliseconds : 161,0582
```

```
λ powershell -command "Measure-Command { python use_pkg_resources.py }"
...
TotalMilliseconds : 307,5465
```

I spent 5 minutes updating pluggy and pytest to use `entrypoints`, and it seems to work fine.

I'm writing this just as a future reference, as we probably should wait to see how `entrypoints` (which is still in version `0.2.3`) and the other modules in the linked issue will actually end up replacing `pkg_resources` in general.

items.title: Introduce attrs?
items.body: I was thinking about introducing [`attrs`](https://github.com/python-attrs/attrs) since I've heard @RonnyPfannschmidt is a fan and I think it would result in a pretty nice cleanup.

items.title: TOC side panel dissapeared in docs
items.body:
[It's gone!](https://pluggy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) :disappointed: 
Is it a theme change?

items.title: Adjust the implprefix DeprecationWarning's stack level
items.body:
Hi!

In #144 a deprecation warning was added for usage of the `implprefix` argument.

However the `warnings.warn()` call doesn't set a `stacklevel`, which means when the warning is output, the blamed line is in pluggy, rather than the plugin that's using `implprefix`. For example:
https://travis-ci.org/mozilla/treeherder/jobs/409417404#L895

Passing `stacklevel=2` would make it clearer as to where the issue lies, and also mean the correct module path can be referenced in eg pytest's `filterwarnings` (for downstream projects who enable warnings/deprecation warnings as errors).

Many thanks :-)

CC @tgoodlet

items.title: Refer to changelog in readme or docs
items.body:
The changelog isn't linked or copied into the docs at the moment.

Personally I like it attached to the readme in the ``long_description``, so one sees it on pypi.org.

They should definitely be included in the docs somehow.

If there is consensus on where it should go then I can make a PR.

items.title: How do wrappers force all results up to the first error?
items.body:
I was thinking about this as I was writing up #142 and realized there seems to be no *public* API way to accomplish this. That is, how does one use a wrapper to stuff all the results up to when the first `hookimpl` fails? Currently `_Result.get_result()` will raise and `_Result.result` is being deprecated so the only way I can think of currently is using the internal `_result` instance var:

```python
@hookimpl(hookwrapper=True):
    outcome = yield
    if test_for_exc_to_swallow(outcome.excinfo):
        outcome.force_result(outcome._result)
        oucome._excinfo = None
```

Maybe this is just a naughty use case and we shouldn't be concerned?

items.title: Keep CHANGELOG updated with PRs?
items.body:
I suggest we keep the CHANGELOG updated as we merge PRs (even so far as making it part of the PR to update the CHANGELOG). Benefits:

* No need to dig around to see which issues have been addressed since the last release, making the job of people making releases (mainly @tgoodlet lately) a lot easier.

* Clear overview of what is about to be released at a glance.

We could adopt `towncrier` like pytest does, but given that `pluggy` does not have the same PR activity as pytest this is not necessary IMO.

items.title: Someone should pin pluggy on the pytest-dev board!
items.body:
I noticed the only 2 projects [pinned thus far](https://github.com/pytest-dev) are `pytest` and `py`.
`pluggy` should be up there too as it's pretty fundamental to the whole ecosystem and is picking up some stars and contributions :)

I'd do it myself but don't have the permissions :(

Ping @RonnyPfannschmidt @nicoddemus @hpk42

items.title: Remove implprefix arg to PluginManager
items.body:
As per discussion in #144 we plan to outright remove the `implprefix` kwarg to `PluginManager` after an appropriate PR has been made to `pytest` implementing the prefix based hook detection/registration.

Further discussion should be made here regarding a possible [strategy pattern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategy_pattern) for hook detection outside of the regular explicit marking mechanism.

An initial thought is to instead offer prefix based registration through a `prefix` kwarg to `PluginManager.register()` if this is a feature we'd like to keep.

items.title: Wheels for 0.6.0 release changed on pypi
items.body:
Currently all our CI tests are failing because on 2018-04-15 the wheels on pypi changed for version 0.6.0 -> https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pluggy

SHA256 of the old wheel: 7f8ae7f5bdf75671a718d2daf0a64b7885f74510bcd98b1a0bb420eb9a9d0cff
SHA256 of the new wheel: d345c8fe681115900d6da8d048ba67c25df42973bda370783cd58826442dcd7c

The tar didn't change.

I don't see any changes between their `__init__.py` file and `callers.py` and assume that maybe now you changed some ignore files so that now less files are packaged (e.g, there's no `LICENSE`, no `testing` etc in the wheel)

Can you confirm that change? Especially with no changes in this repository this is concerning and changes to existing releases really should never happen.

items.title: How to best add and act on custom metadata for hookspec_opts and hookimpl_opts
items.body:
I'm looking to figure out the best way to deprecate a hook we have provided to end users and might be implemented in some plugins already. In a more general sense, I want to be able to add my own metadata to spec and impl opts and have ways of acting on that inside pluggy itself.

For the record, I have considered registering a try-first implementation or hook wrapper that raises the deprecation warning. And that's the easy answer, but I'd like to be able to include this information in documentation of the spec itself (potentially through a sphinx plugin or something similar) so inserting it into the `spec_opts` seemed like the wiser thing to do. From there, I'd also like to be able to act on it in the hook caller.

[However, I found this difficult](https://gist.github.com/justanr/6211ebda282f92803015ac7216eb5d90) mostly because of that static calls to `_HookCaller` that required copying large amounts of code into a subclass. Some of it could be cut down -- for example `_HookCaller.__call__` doesn't need to be overridden only `_HookCaller._hookexec` needs to be intercepted and wrapped.

I understand that I'm poking at things that are probably not intended to be poked at, or at least weren't considered open to being poked at. But is there potential for opening them up to poking?

items.title: Automate wheels generation and pypi upload in TravisCI
Question about the "right" way for writing plugins
items.body:
I started looking into pluggy more and thought about how to use it right from the perspective of a plugin writer. I looked through the docs and came to the conclusion that the right way of doing stuff is to use the pluggy API to create a hookimpl object instead of importing it from the host project. I started changing the tox code and opened a whole slew of PRs to change to the "right" way. Long story short - I might have been a bit trigger happy and now I would like to clarify this and then either go ahead or undo the damage. My opinion at the moment is that using the pluggy API explicitly is the right way rather than importing the hookimpl from the host. In tox we already have the problem of several hookimpl objects that are imported by plugins. So I am talking about

    import pluggy
    hookimpl = pluggy.HookImplMarker("project")

vs

    from project.where.ever.it.lives import hookimpl

@ryanhiebert argues that the plugin writer doesn't have to care and should not have to do this and instead get the hookimpl marker directly from the host. I have to admit that this makes a lot of sense, but atm I am still torn, so I would be interested what the official view of the core devs is. Reading the docs again with that perspective in mind it seems clear that hookimpl should be imported. Also taking this further means that the underlying plugin implementation could be replaced as long as the marker object, decorator args and passed in objects stay the same, so importing the object might be the better idea from that perspective also.
 
Once this is clarified one or the other way I would volunteer to enhance the docs to make it clearer how this should be done and why.

Also cc @asottile who already started using that approach in another project that is not in tox-dev.

affected PRs:

https://github.com/tox-dev/detox/pull/12
https://github.com/tox-dev/tox-durations/pull/3
https://github.com/tox-dev/tox-pipenv/pull/40
https://github.com/tox-dev/tox-travis/pull/103

items.title: aiopluggy
items.body:
Hi all,

Sorry, this is gonna be a long post. Let me start with what I did last week...

Looking for a good Python plugin manager, I quickly found `pluggy`. I really liked its design, but couldn't use it in its current form: I'm working on a pluggable [aiohttp](https://github.com/aio-libs/aiohttp) service, and many of my *hook functions* will be *asynchronous*; that is, they will return a coroutine that must be *awaited*.

So, I forked from `pluggy` and adapted it to work with asynchronous plugins.

To me, it seems impossible to do this in a backward compatible way: `HookCaller.__call__()` and `PluginManager.register()` need to become coroutine functions, to just name some examples. Knowing that I couldn't be backward compatible anyway, I renamed my repository to `aiopluggy` and made more breaking changes.


So, the current status is:

- The repository can be found at https://github.com/Amsterdam/aiopluggy
- Documentation can be found at https://aiopluggy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
- Everything is still "work in progress": notably, tests are incomplete and some of the original functionality (tracing, registry manipulation) is still missing.

Once it's stable, I would like to see `aiopluggy` become part of the [aio-libs](https://github.com/aio-libs/) collection.

Of course, I don't want to proceed before telling you about what I've been doing, and ask what you think of it. Also, I don't know what the "rules" are when it comes to copyright ownership. I'd hate to "adorn with borrowed plumes" on `aiopluggy`, so I kept the authorship and list of contributors intact. Still, if anyone feels my actions so far are inappropriate, please let me know so I can make it right.


A short list of the most important changes I made to the interface:
- auto-detection of asynchronous, coroutine hook functions, which will be *awaited* at call-time.
- changed the syntax of hook marker options: instead of `@hookimplmarker(tryfirst=True)` you'll now write `@hookimplmarker.try_first`.
- auto-detection of hook wrappers. I'm not happy about this myself, though ;-(
- Removed deprecated code, including the legacy ``__multicall__`` parameter handling.
- Renamed from **pluggy** to **aiopluggy**
- Removed compatibility with Python versions before 3.5.
- Updated documentation.

I'm curious about what you think.

Kind regards,
Pieter

items.title: document implprefix argument?
items.body:
Hi,
I'm new to the project and I'm considering using pluggy in my own application.
So I started by looking at pluggy's documentation, as well as the way it's being used by pytest.

While looking at the latter, I noticed that the `PluginManager` can also take a `implprefix` argument in order to search for matching names in a plugin namespace to be registered as hook implementations.
I also noticed pytest plugins have hooks prefixed with "pytest_", and it doesn't seem necessary to mark implementations with `pytest.hookimpl` decorator to make them discoverable; the latter is of course required if one wishes to customize the behavior of a hook (by passing options to the decorator like hookwrapper, optionalhook, etc.).

As far as I can see, the main pluggy documentation at http://pluggy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ only mentions the `HookimplMarker` decorator as the way to mark a function for detection by a PluginManager's `register` method.
It's true that `implprefix` is mentioned in the "Public API" section of the docs, as it's in the PluginManager's docstring. However, maybe it could be featured more prominently in the main section?

Or is this intentional and the decorator approach is the method which should be preferred for detection of hook implementations?

Thank you

items.title: Turn _MultiCall into a function
items.body:
Now that #23 has landed it seems fit that we evaluate the [`_MultiCall`](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pluggy/blob/master/pluggy/callers.py#L58) type.

Afaict this class contains a single method `execute()` other then `__init__` (and `__repr__` but who uses it?) and that method was only necessary for the original recursive implementation.

I'm wondering can we simplify the whole thing into a simple function? 

Reasons for:
- `_MultiCall` keeps no state since it's execute method [is always called directly after instantiation](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pluggy/blob/master/pluggy/__init__.py#L233)
- `_MultiCall` instances are never *reused*
- having a function is less code, faster and arguably easier to cythonize

items.title: Document the `pluggy._Result` API
items.body:
Currently [`pluggy._CallOutcome`](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pluggy/blob/master/pluggy.py#L200) is implied to be part of the internal api by the leading `_`.

In practice it is used by [`hookwrappers`](https://pluggy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/#wrappers).

An example:
```python
@pytest.hookimpl(tryfirst=True, hookwrapper=True)
def pytest_runtest_makereport(item, call):
    outcome = yield
    rep = outcome.get_result() 
    ...
```
The `outcome` is accessed directly by the user.
Therefore I propose we expose it correct in `plugg.__all__` and expose it in the [api reference](https://pluggy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api_reference.html).

items.title: Strict mode(s) - change validation rules dynamically?
items.body:
As per pytest-dev/pytest#1821 @RonnyPfannschmidt has mentioned it's worth discussing if `pluggy.PluginManager` should have a *strict* mode where every single plugin which is loaded is verified against a spec instead of only performing this validation each time `PluginManager.check_pending()` is called.

In `pytest` `check_pending()` is only done once just prior to the `pytest_cmdline_main(config=config)` call meaning unverified hooks can be loaded any time afterwards.

This issue is to open discussion and brainstorming.

items.title: Deprecate __multicall__ support
items.body:
As per the comment in [`pluggy._MultiCall`](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pluggy/blob/master/pluggy.py#L586) we should be able to drop the line [here](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pluggy/blob/master/pluggy.py#L613). Grepping the `pytest` sources reveals that only a [few spots still reference it](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=__multicall__).

This change also allows us to remove the recursion induced by [`_wrapped_call()` getting passed `_MultiCall.execute`](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pluggy/blob/master/pluggy.py#L613). This means we can remove `_wrapped_call` and simply loop through hookwrapper pre and post `yield` calls at the beginning and end of `execute()`. I'd actually be interested to see if `contextlib.contextmanager` wrapping could be used directly for this.

items.title: Marking hookspec as requiring at least one implementation
items.body:
For some hooks it would be great if I could make an implementation for it mandatory, so that it doesn't just do nothing but raises an Error when called.
What are your thoughts on that?

items.title: Can't load instances which define hook specs
items.body:
You currently can't instantiate a class which defines hook specs prior to loading

``` python
import pluggy

hookspec = pluggy.HookspecMarker('example')

class SpecSpace(object):
    @hookspec
    def myhook(self, stuff):
        """My custom hook spec.
        """

pluggy.PluginManager('example').add_hookspecs(SpecSpace())
```

because `pluggy.varnames()` doesn't successfully detect and remove the `self` name.

I realize this is an odd usage (and implied to be illegal based on the argname to `add_hookspecs()`) but it is conceivable. A contrived example might be where a user wishes to define the spec and the default hook implementation using the same function:

``` python
import pluggy

hookspec = pluggy.HookspecMarker('example')
hookimpl = pluggy.HookimplMarker('example')

class SpecSpace(object):
    def __init__(self, arg):
        self.arg = arg 

    @hookimpl
    @hookspec
    def hook1(self, stuff):
        """My custom hook spec.
        """
        if self.arg = 'doggy' and stuff == 'blah':
             # do this one thing
        else:
            # do this other thing

ss = SpecSpace('blah')
pm = pluggy.PluginManager('example')
pm.add_hookspecs(ss)
pm.register(ss)
```

I guess it's kind of silly...

Either way the implementation of `pluggy.varnames` is quite outdated and should be changed to more properly levarage the `inspect` module. If we prefer to not ever allow instances then a more explicit error should be thrown in `PluginManager.add_hookspecs()`

items.title: better error when a attribute named like a hook is an module
items.body:
pytest-dev/pytest#1686

trouble happened when i tried to use a package as a plugin while it had a module named `pytest_store`

items.title: support defaults to enable deprecation
items.body:
this is to help pytest-dev/pytest#1372

the idea is, that if a hook is invoked with a missing, but specced argument, then the default is used instead

so if a hook caller would call `hook.pytest_deselected(items=...)'
and the hook was defined with`def pytest_deselected(items, reason='No Reason Given)`
then the receivers would receive the defined default reason

in order to support deprecation of such usage we could later devise a mark for deprecated defaults

items.title: high level overview
items.body:
The description "as used by py.test" is not very helpful. To be able to compare with other known plugin systems like Trac, SCons , Roundup or Spyder I need to answer the questions:
1. how plugin discovery is made
2. how plugin loading happens
3. when plugin initialization occurs

items.body:
I am seeing the following error (end of traceback), when running `py.test`:

```
  File "…/pytest/_pytest/config.py", line 917, in _preparse
    self.pluginmanager.load_setuptools_entrypoints("pytest11")
  File "…/pluggy/pluggy.py", line 501, in load_setuptools_entrypoints
    plugin = ep.load()
  File "…/pyenv/velodrome/lib/python3.4/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2354, in load
    self.require(*args, **kwargs)
  File "…/pyenv/velodrome/lib/python3.4/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2371, in require
    items = working_set.resolve(reqs, env, installer)
  File "…/pyenv/velodrome/lib/python3.4/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 844, in resolve
```
